Message.Title: Guaranteed 7.75% yield, No bull
Message.Msg: Buy it now, get a nice yield! CYS Investments Inc., 7.75% Series A Cumulative Redeemable Preferred Stock, liquidation preference $25 per share, redeemable at the issuer's option on or after 8/3/2017 at $25 per share plus accrued and unpaid dividends, and with no stated maturity. Cumulative distributions of 7.75% per annum ($1.9375 per annum or $0.484375 per quarter) will be paid quarterly on 1/15, 4/15, 7/15 & 10/15 to holders of record on the record date that will be the first calendar day of the month in which the payment is due (NOTE: the ex-dividend date is at least 2 business days prior to the record date). Upon the occurrence of a change of control the company will have the option within 120 days to redeem the preferred shares at $25 per share plus accrued and unpaid dividends.

Message.Title: maybe i just cant add but
Message.Msg: for yhoo to declare cash div and pay before dec 31 to avoid much higher tax rate for shareholders, they will have to announce x date in next 30 days or so. if its a buyback vs cash then 22% of stock is going to disappear from market. either way the end of story is very positive for shareholders when you compound this action knowing they are going to get another 6b for their remaining holdings in near future. both gs and s&p have a 21 target on stock. and as long as i am being stupid, if i was going to acquire yhoo i would do it now and get my hands on the 14b in new cash coming from alibaba. its 8 ps which means current market is pricing yhoo at 8ps for an operation with no debt and 1b in cash flow.

Message.Title: Big picture and the last 2 months.
Message.Msg: Yahoo has been stuck in the mid teens for quite a while. Daily movements of the stock are being driven mainly by news releases of the company along with the changes that are happening. So the new CEO steps in and says well we may not give shareholders everything that the previous CEO had promised. To be honest I respect that...the CEO needs to evaluate where funds are going to be spent and where the investments are going to be made. I would have been more upset if mgt didn't do anything. She has brought in new blood from Google and has done a lot of things to try and improve employee morale which from my reading she has accomplished. So they are now buying lunch, giving employees smartphones, and plan on throwing a really good holiday party. Again it all falls back to keeping employee morale high and retaining talent. When you think that a headhunter is paid 1/3 of a new hires first year pay its not a bad move. It is painful to watch the stock flounder but present management has to be given some time to get the company moving in the right direction. There are people who trade the stock on a daily basis and some people who believe that a fistful of shorts with a couple thousand shares will move the stock one way or another. What it all comes down to is being able to show the institutional community that the company can grow revenue and increase earnings. If that is accomplished the stock will begin to climb higher...simple as that.

Topic.Title: Time For a Two Week Vacation!

Topic.Title: Big picture and the last 2 months.

Message.Msg: That would certainly be an interesting match up. Even if something like that does not happen it appears that management is creating a deep bench of talent along with retaining the talent that they have. Thats the way you run a business...you have to think that the senior managers who left google will begin to pull their teams over as well. It will take some time for the company to start firing on all cylinders but they have plenty of cash and a good turn around story. A couple good news releases and we will be mid 17's. This is a long term play...not a sprint.

Topic.Title: Big picture and the last 2 months.

Message.Title: Baby BaWaHoo Chooses Android
Message.Msg: In his first fit of child temper, and his anger at being slapped to life stuck in a Yahoo family, Baby BaWaHoo has got his first cell phone in the Yahoo freebie program, and chosen a Samsung Galaxy S3 in defiance of his mother, who wanted a Windows phone for him. Apparently, like Mewag and others, she has come to the conclusion that only by Ballmer buying YHOO can her stock options ever get above 16, so better support MSFT. Word has it she is consulting Scott Thompson for ideas again, as she has none of her own that she didn't steal from him. Thompson just doesn't fit into the future bar mitzvah plans for Baby BaWaHoo, which are already rumored to approach $5 million in the planning. Unfortunately, Mayer is also being kept busy refuting rumors that the baby was born in Kenya, and is destined to be future King BaWaHoo, of the crumbling empire once known as Yahoo.

Topic.Title: Big picture and the last 2 months.

Message.Msg: Time will tell. As many have noted, it looks like Yahoo is setting itself up to be sold. It's all about mobile at this point, and yahoo will put forth everything they have into that. It would be a perfect fit to have all those iphones and siri spouting of the latest yahoo content or search results. I think one of the mobile companies will buy out yahoo and there are only a couple that seem to fit the bill. Apple is tops on that list. I'm in at 14.84, so I can afford to be patient and see how this plays out.

Topic.Title: earnings oct 22 at 2pm- very unusal day-monday and very unsual time 2pm, its never during the day-hmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm

Message.Msg: Da^n man, this is the second time today you posted some stupid sh^t. Do you try to understand what your reading when you read? The time you indicate is for the conference call, not earnings release...and the time is Pacific so that is 5pm eastern, a normal time. There is nothing unusual EXCEPT!!! YHOO has not confirmed the earnings release...it is printed for the 15th, the 16th and rumored to be after close on the 12th. If anyone has a firm earnings release time confirmed, let me know. The YHOO web site has not date for special events posted for earnings release as of now...this I find unusual..usually they go with the third Tuesday of the month following the quarter end. I sure can read a lot into an earnings release combined with cash distribution plan released after market close on Fridat the 12th. But who know. I think MM will take a couple hours off from mom duty (GO MM) and make some statement, this is her first quarterly report as responsible CEO.

And, with the history of buybacks for underperforming stock, what is the benefit to the shareholder if the stock doesn't rise? Oh.....they just all like to profess their love for Marissa, and sure she'll turn things around. So, will they get in early now and buy the stock...........NOT. Carol Bartz, potty mouth and all, had us at $18/sh!! It's just like high school, I guess the world just loves a bright, pretty, yuppy queen.

Now it's a good time for Alibaba to go public after waiting for so many years to get back its control. EPS should be rising due to continues stock buyback.

Topic.Title: Cash Dividend or Buyback?

Message.Msg: That Alipay fiasco was under the watch of Jerry Yang, who was on the board of directors for Alibaba. The mystery of how that happened right under his nose will never be answered, can't blame Bartz for that. Who would expect that to happen with a founder on the board? One of the other "mysteries" of Yahoo, is how both founders, Yang and Filo, lost their edge, (aside of Yang's investment in Alibba), not contributing anything significant over the last 5 years. I was depressed when I read that Marissa Mayer was "leaning" on Filo for ideas....where's he been buried?!! Google's founders, Apple's founders, all went on to build their companies into greater enterprises. Jerry Yang got into golf, and David Filo obviously likes selling his free options and counting the money.

Message.Title: Yahoo!'s core business worth at least $7.17 a share
Message.Msg: So what's the real value hidden inside Yahoo!? Cramer said the company's remaining stake in the Chinese Alibaba is worth at least $5.8 billion, while its Yahoo Japan assets can add on another $4.77 billion. Add that total to the $5.84 per share of cash the company has on hand and Yahoo! is already valued at $14.84 a share, leaving its core U.S. businesses, including mail, sports, finance, Flickr and more, valued at just $1 per share. Cramer said that Yahoo!'s core business is worth at least $7.17 a share, taking the total value up to $22 a share. He said with Mayer at the helm, it's easy to think the stock will begin to move once the company reports on Oct. 22 and outlines more of its plans.
